title: Franco Reviglio
text:
Franco Reviglio (born 3 February 1935) is an <a href="Italians">Italian</a> academic, businessman and socialist politician, who served in various capacities in the public administration of Italy.
Early life and education.
Reviglio was born in <a href="Turin">Turin</a> in 1935. He was also educated in Turin. His undergraduate thesis was about improving efficiency in state-owned companies.
Career.
Reviglio worked as a professor of public finance at the <a href="University%20of%20Turin">University of Turin</a>. He was a member of <a href="Italian%20Socialist%20Party">the Socialist Party</a> and served as the <a href="Italian%20Minister%20of%20Finance">minister of finance</a> from 4 August 1979 to 28 June 1981 in the <a href="Cossiga%20I%20Cabinet">cabinet</a> led by <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Italy">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Francesco%20Cossiga">Francesco Cossiga</a>. After working at the University of Turin for two more years he left his job in 1983 and became the president of the Italian energy firm Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, which is commonly known as <a href="Eni">ENI</a>. He was appointed to the post in order to reorganize and improve the firm. He achieved these goals in large degree. In fact, ENI witnessed one of its most successful periods when he led the firm. He supported <a href="privatization">privatization</a> as a means of reorganizing asset portfolios and investment strategies. Reviglio's tenure at the firm ended in November 1989, and <a href="Umberto%20Colombo%20%28scientist%29">Umberto Colombo</a> succeeded him in the post. 
On 5 June 1990, Reviglio joined as a senior advisor to <a href="Wasserstein%20Perella%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Wasserstein Perella & Co.</a>'s team in regard to its European operations and held the post until 1992. In 1992, he was appointed budget minister in <a href="Amato%20I%20Cabinet">the cabinet</a> led by Prime Minister <a href="Giuliano%20Amato">Giuliano Amato</a>. His tenure lasted until February 1993, and he was replaced by <a href="Beniamino%20Andreatta">Beniamino Andreatta</a> as budget minister. Reviglio was appointed finance minister in a cabinet reshuffle on 21 February 1993. He succeeded <a href="Giovanni%20Goria">Giovanni Goria</a> in the post. Reviglio resigned from office on 30 March 1993 due to his alleged involvement in bribery scandal. He also served as a member of municipal council of Turin and as a senator (1992 – 1994).
After leaving office and politics, Reviglio returned to his teaching post at the University of Turin. He also assumed the role of senior advisor to <a href="Lehman%20Brothers">Lehman Brothers</a> from 2002 to 2007. He is the former president and CEO of Azienda Energetica Metropolitana Torino SpA (Turin Energy Company; 2000 – 2006) as well as the president of NNOICOM, TLC company. He is the emeritus professor at the University of Turin.
